issue.title: Issue with SSL / TLS and self-signed server certificates
issue.body:
Hi,

Sending encrypted messages on servers presenting self-signed certificates or on shared environment where server certificate does not match domain name results in exception like the following one:

> exception 'ErrorException' with message 'stream_socket_enable_crypto(): Peer certificate CN=`*.servername.com' did not match expected CN=`mail.domain.com'' in \home\vendor\swiftmailer\swiftmailer\lib\classes\Swift\Transport\StreamBuffer.php:95

I sugggest adding configuration parameter "Skip certificate validation", so method **_establishSocketConnection** of the **Swift_Transport_StreamBuffer** class could add the following in case this parameter is set to true:

`$options['ssl'] = ['allow_self_signed' => true, 'verify_peer' => false, 'verify_peer_name' => false];`

That would effectively prevent the above mentioned exception from occurrence.

issue.title: Add Swift_Transport::ping()
issue.body:
I have a long-running PHP job that occasionally sends email.

Unless I explicitly stop the SMTP connection after each use, the SMTP server may eventually close the connection if it has not been used for an extended period. This will make the next send() operation throw an exception.

This patch adds a ping() method similar to that in [Doctrine\DBAL\Connection::ping()](https://github.com/doctrine/dbal/blob/master/lib/Doctrine/DBAL/Connection.php#L1560).

Apart from the addition of ping() to the Swift_Transport interface, this change is backwards compatible and can be merged into the current release branch.

issue.title: Mime Boundary not correct
issue.body:
Hi I'm from https://www.sparkpost.com/ and noticed something with SwiftMailer MIME boundary.

SwiftMailer produces a mime boundary [here](https://github.com/swiftmailer/swiftmailer/blob/5.x/lib/classes/Swift/Mime/SimpleMimeEntity.php#L412) 
The _interesting_ thing is it uses `=` as part of the characters in the boundary  #sequence.

According to RFC2046 `_` and `=` are valid in mime boundary
See: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2046

```
boundary := 0*69<bchars> bcharsnospace

     bchars := bcharsnospace / " "

     bcharsnospace := DIGIT / ALPHA / "'" / "(" / ")" /
                      "+" / "_" / "," / "-" / "." /
                      "/" / ":" / "=" / "?"
```

The multi-parts message spec is not specific on whether the boundary value should be quoted or not, and it does say that some non-alphanumeric characters/punctuations are legal. However, if not in quotes, the presence of some of the non-alphanumeric characters does break other RFCs concerning header field (e.g. RFC2822, RFC2045). So, if, e.g. there will be '=' or '-' or ' ' (whitespace) or ';' etc. among the boundary value, code should add quotes around it. Overall, it's a good practice that the boundary be treated just as attributes of other headers - always quote it, so that a clean attribute=value pair can be identified.

It is helpful to search RFC2046 for `boundary=` and note that simple boundary are not quoted but anytime a non [a-z][A-Z][0-9] character is used the boundary is quoted.

In testing this causes intermittent problems when sending attachments.

I propose remove `=` from boundary (to make things more reliable) and quote the boundary sequence so it will appear like this:

Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="_X_swift_v4_1458901746_7c7276005fa2659f6ddd6a4e60f7ccea_X_"

issue.title: Expose _userContentType
issue.body:
I need a way to get the content type of the message body after a part has been added. After such a part has been added, `$message->getContentType()` changes to `multipart/alternative`, and even though I can get the body with `getBody()` I can't get its type.

Am I missing something, or is it impossible to get this at the moment?

It seems to me either the type should be set to `multipart/alternative` at send time rather than earlier, so a user can still get at the body and its type. Or when a part is added the existing body should immediately become a child and be accessed as such, and then the message's type can change. But perhaps there are good design decisions for the way things currently work which I'm missing.

(I posted on Stackoverflow with [a question about how to retrieve this value](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/36025109/swiftmailer-get-body-contenttype-after-a-part-has-been-added) before digging into the code and finding this.)

issue.title: Broken attachment
Saving Sent Emails.
issue.body:
It would be nice to be able to save sent emails.

Since I was using the decorator plugin for bulk sending there was no way to do it. 

So for anyone else I create a setPath function on the decorator plugin, with a private var in the class and set this after instantiation.

when building the decorator array I included a "message_id" for which related to the address (which can be looked up in the DB - also means they are unique).

Then when the decorator plugin runs - 

file_puts_contents($this->_savePath.$replacements['{message_id}'].'.eml',$message->toString());

There are of course other ways to do it - probably best to create your own class, add it to the Send Event so it runs on its own and can simply be added rather than hard coding into Decorator - you could then add it to Log, send, or where ever needed.

issue.title: Headers QP encoder uses wrong alphabet
issue.body:

the body of this override method initializes safe map using truncated alphabet of symbols ([a-zA-Z0-9 *-\/]), that is at least symbols [?:.,'()+_] are missing (while they are perfectly valid for eg. boundary part of 'Content-Type' header,  rfc 2046 http://www.rfc-editor.org/info/rfc2046)

issue.title: Insecure unserialize possible with Swift_ByteStream_TemporaryFileByteStream
issue.body:
The class `Swift_ByteStream_TemporaryFileByteStream` has the `__destruct()` method which will be called after `unserialize()`.

If this class does not need to support for serialization, consider implementing the method `__wakeup()` and throwing an exception.

A similar problem is in Swift_KeyCache_DiskKeyCache, Swift_Mime_SimpleMimeEntity

Let me know if I should create a PR.

issue.title: [5.X] BUG - Return types for getTo(), getCc() and getBcc()
issue.body:
`\Swift_Mime_SimpleMessage` implements the `\Swift_Mime_Message` interface, which states the following functions should return `string[]` arrays only:
- `\Swift_Mime_Message::getTo()`
- `\Swift_Mime_Message::getCc()`
- `\Swift_Mime_Message::getBcc()`

But these functions may return `null` instead of empty arrays. The interface is thus not respected and a bug can occur.

@fabpot @xdecock , I am willing to provide a PR to fix that, but which way round ?
- Shall the interface be updated to indicate these functions can also return `null` ?
- OR Shall the concrete implementations be updated so that they only return `string[]` arrays ?

issue.title: Validating a message-id on a received email when used in Reply-To
issue.body:
There is a bug in the code which validates addresses as it marked a Reply-To address as invalid even though that message-id had been generated elsewhere and was received as a valid email. This meant that I could not send out a reply to that valid email. The only way I could do so was to comment out this validation completely.

It is bad practice to validate a message-id that has been received as it has already been validated by the sending party. The message-id on any received message MUST be valid, therefore any revalidation is totally redundant.

issue.title: Quoted-printable subject (header) encoding bug
issue.body:
When encoding headers and subject in particular, Swiftmailer tries to 'tokenize' (split into words) subject apparently trying to detect whether it should be encoded (Unicode) or left intact (ASCII).

There are bugs, however, which result in spaces between words being stripped and other encoding oddities.

Spaces between words are sometimes lost when subject is a mix of unicode and ASCII and encoding is quoted-printable:
Subject 'Добро пожаловать на Site.ru' encoded in quoted-printable:
Subject: =?utf-8?Q?=D0=94=D0=BE=D0=B1=D1=80=D0=BE_=D0=BF=D0=BE?=
 =?utf-8?Q?=D0=B6=D0=B0=D0=BB=D0=BE=D0=B2=D0=B0=D1=82=D1=8C_=D0=BD=D0=B0?=
 Site.ru

Missing space before 'Site.ru'. Some e-mail clients show space correctly, but some doesn't.

Subject encoded in base64 also looks strange:
Subject: =?utf-8?B?0JTQvtCx0YDQvg==?=
 =?utf-8?B??=  =?utf-8?B?0L/QvtC20LDQu9C+0LLQsNGC0Yw=?=

Should encoding prefix '=?utf-8?' be prefixing each word?

Also, If two spaces are inserted between words, mail clients are not seeing them at all after tokenized encoding.

There was no configurable way to set header encoding to Base64, requiring hacks to 'mime_deps.php'. 

I also had to patch /swiftmailer/lib/classes/Swift/Mime/Headers/AbstractHeader.php
to make function tokenNeedsEncoding($token) always return false, to prevent encoding of subject and then in the client doing it yourself:
    ->setSubject('=?utf-8?B?'.base64_encode($subj).'?=')

This makes subject encoded as one b64 string (with one prefix), which is perfectly recognized by webmail and email clients which didn't show it correctly before. No issues with lost spaces or incorrect token encodings. Not sure why this "tokenization" is required at all for base64 encoded data.

issue.title: Don't regenerate message-id after sending mail
issue.body:
All the Swift_Transport handlers regenerate the message-id by calling message->generateId() after a send() is performed. 

Basically $message is modified and so ->toString() and getId() no-longer reflect the actual mail that was sent. This is not okay.

There are multiple GitHub issues that are based on this problem.

issue.title: Swift_Mime_MimePart::_convertString() converts string incorrectly
issue.body:
We use the iso-8859-15 charset and found that Swift does some incorrect converting in Swift_Mime_MimePart::_convertString().
In this method the mb_convert_encoding() is called with the following parameters:
mb_convert_encoding('Berbée', 'iso-8859-15', 'utf-8');

This results in 'Berb?e'

I'm not sure why the encoding is skipped when utf-8 or iso-8859-1 is used (those charsets aren't the same right?).
It seems it tries to encode the string to the specified charset, but in this case, the given string already is iso-8859-15. Also the $from_encoding param for
mb_convert_encoding shouldn't be utf-8, because it is iso-8859-15. It is strange to assume the source is always utf-8.

Why is '_convertString()' even called in setBody()? Shouldn't you believe that the string is encoded with the given charset?
I hope someone can take a look at this method, because when using a different charset than utf-8 or iso-8859-1, it will cause strings to be encoded incorrectly.

issue.title: $failedRecipients dupes
issue.body:
Swift_Mailer::send() can return duplicate email addresses in its second argument - $failedRecipients array (if for ex. for whatever reason the same email is specified in To/CC/BCC fields). 
The same can happen for Swift_FileSpool::flushQueue() which sends multiple messages that can have the same invalid (rejected by transport) email address.

This does not make sense and should be fixed ($failedRecipients array must not contain dupes).

issue.title: DKIM header not seperated from Message-ID
issue.body:
There is an issue where the header fields "DKIM-Signature" and "Message-ID" are mixed up into one single header which results into the following:

```
DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha1; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=domain.com; s=mail;
    t=1437574424; i=@domain.com; bh=2jmj7l5rSw0yVb/vlWAYkK/YBwk=;
    h=Message-ID:Date:Subject:From:To:MIME-Version:Content-Type;
    b=rXhMit3rNzhNU8qVsEYQtCWqIzbHdAdrHhLQtBFeCuODmLqHNUQkv52XUWkT8C/AqFh3
     ODnYHMXzVFmJaVh9lIXdf66l4oCx85lpdDnP7dowwk38GWjn/h1VphgkNN1lkZl3JFvfG
     6gid0inPDPhNOiDf4kY5MwFdnZDT2c/F0g=Message-ID: <a0050431c8aefd6004ae66bfefa5ce13@domain.com>
```

There's simply a line break missing.

My setup is as follows:

``` php
$mailer = Swift_Mailer::newInstance(Swift_SmtpTransport::newInstance('localhost', 25));
$signer = new Swift_Signers_OpenDKIMSigner(
    file_get_contents('/path/to/private.certificate.pem'),
    'domain.com',
    'mail');
$signer->setBodyCanon('relaxed')
    ->setHeaderCanon('relaxed');
$message = Swift_Message::newInstance($subject)
    ->setFrom(array('noreply@domain.com' => 'domain'))
    ->setTo($email, $nick)
    ->setBody($mailview->render('email.phtml'), 'text/html')
    ->addPart($mailview->render('email-text.phtml'), 'text/plain')
    ->attachSigner($signer);
return $mailer->send($message);
```

I've created a workaround where I modified Swift_Signers_OpenDKIMSigner::addSignature() in line 52 from

``` php
$header->setValue($headerVal);
```

to

``` php
$header->setValue($headerVal . PHP_EOL);
```

which resolves the issue but is quite quick & dirty.

issue.title: Message body for non-UTF-8 multipart emails gets converted twice

Tested with latest Swiftmail (5.4.1)

issue.title: Quoted-printable encoder exceeds 76-character limit
issue.body:
**Sample code**

```
$factory = new Swift_CharacterReaderFactory_SimpleCharacterReaderFactory();
$charStream = new Swift_CharacterStream_NgCharacterStream($factory, 'iso-8859-1');
$encoder =  new Swift_Encoder_QpEncoder($charStream);
$input = str_repeat('a', 74) . ' ';
$output = $encoder->encodeString($input);
```

**Expected result**

```
string(81) "aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa=
=20"
```

**Actual result (longer than 76-character limit)**

```
string(77) "aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa=20"
```

issue.title: Swift Mailer - 500 Internal Server Error
Content-Type: multipart/related not set when needed
issue.body:
When I'm embedding images into the HTML body of an email, the global Content-Type is set to multipart/mixed. This is fine with many email readers (such as Gmail, Zimbra, ...) but it does not display anything with Mozilla Thunderbird for instance.

A workaround consist, at the end of the email composition process, to run:
$message->setContentType('multipart/related');
in the case where embedded images are present.

I'm not sure but I think that the RFC says that the Content-Type needs to be set on multipart/related if any image is embedded into the body of an email... and this is not the default behavior of SwiftMailer (and it took me hours to find this out)

issue.title: Allow to get the filename used in FileSpool
issue.body:
When a message is spooled to file, [`FileSpool` generates a random string](https://github.com/swiftmailer/swiftmailer/blob/master/lib/classes/Swift/FileSpool.php#L92-L112) but it is not possible to reuse it.

If the `SpoolTransport` was able to get the `$fileName` it could also add it to the `SendEvent` [here](https://github.com/swiftmailer/swiftmailer/blob/master/lib/classes/Swift/Transport/SpoolTransport.php#L98-L103).

Any reason why the `$fileName` is not returned? I'd like to use it to allow the user to cancel sending an email. Shouldn't the `FileSpool` make use of the `Mime_Message::generateId()`? That would allow us to locate the spooled email later.

issue.title: Misleading SSL/TLS option
issue.body:
The security argument of Swift_SmtpTransport is misleading with the naming.

```
'ssl' => SMTP over SSL/TLS (recommended port: 465)
'tls' => STARTTLS (SSL/TLS) over TCP (recommended port: 587)
```

`'ssl'` can also use the [TLS protocol](https://www.fastmail.fm/help/technical/ssltlsstarttls.html). Since SSLv3 are widely disabled, only the TLS protocol is used. It would be clearer, if the options are called differently.
This is a BC break, if the security options are called differently.

An possible solution to this problem would be to an autodetection of the SSL or STARTTLS. If the argument 'security' is set to 'true', it first tries to establish an SSL connection, if it's not working, try reestablish an 'TCP' connection and look for the Capability of 'STARTTLS'.

issue.title: Add support for a standard way to handle OOF auto reply
issue.body:
We're delivering a lot of mail, something like 160.000 per month, and sometimes, users are "Out of office" for vacation. 
When we're in vacation periods, we receive tons of mail saying "I'm in vacation"... and this is annoying :).

I assume this is a common issue you have to deal with, this is why I'm asking that:
It would be great to have an option that automatically include the correct headers to avoid a reply when users are in vacation.

As far as we know, it exists these headers:
- Precedence: bulk
- X-Precedence: bulk
- X-Autoreply: yes
- Auto-Submitted: auto-generated
- X-Auto-Response-Suppress: all 
  But some headers lead to be seen as spammers by some anti-spam mechanisms.

I performed ​​some tests by playing with these different headers. I only kept Precedence: bulk and Auto-Submitted: auto-generated because the other had not the targeted effect.

Here is a draft that brings to swiftmailer a standard way to solve this issue.

issue.title: Could not provide a specific certificate for TLS connections
issue.body:
The SwiftMailer does not provide a way to specify a specific SSL certificate for TLS connections.

StreamBuffer::_establishSocketConnection() contains the following code:
$this->_stream = @stream_socket_client(..., stream_context_create($options));

Based on http://php.net/stream_context_create and http://php.net/manual/en/context.ssl.php, the certificate can be specified by a $params parameter. Unfortunately, there is no extension point in Swift allowing to set it.

issue.title: Cannot use "Name" <address> format for setFrom
issue.body:
In our case our from address is already translated into the header format "Name" <address>, however if we pass that string into setFrom it complains that the address is invalid according to RFC 2822.

Since this was the format PEAR::Mail and other mail clients require, it's the format we use throughout our application.  Obviously we could write a fairly simple regex to grab the name and address separately, but since they are going to end up back in this format, and it's quite common, I think support for it deserves to be in the library.

issue.title: Sending Messages documentation small error - mail function additional parameters note
issue.body: On this page: http://swiftmailer.org/docs/sending.html#the-mail-transport in the section about the mail transport there's a note on $additional_parameters. Below it is an example, but it doesn't illustrate the note's content. Instead of $transport = Swift_MailTransport::newInstance(); it should probably say that you can do this: $transport = Swift_MailTransport::newInstance('-f contact@example.com'); or that to make the $additional_parameters blank you can do this: $transport = Swift_MailTransport::newInstance(''); Regards

issue.title: Trying to send email to recipient like "test..test@gmail.com" causes \Swift_RfcComplienceException.
Error Message with File Attachment
Line-break in subject not correct, if subject contains multiple spaces
issue.body:
If the subject string contains multiple spaces ("    ") and those spaces happen to get located at the end of the line (forced by the 70-somewhat character limit), Swift Mailer doesn't replace them correctly (with something like \r\n\t for the line break), but rather leaves them as is. Thereby, they get effectively lost (i.e. not displayed by the receiving mail client).

Version: Swift Mailer 5.0.3

Cheers,
Thomas

issue.title: Multiple BCCs failing
RSET not sent between multiple mesages in a session
issue.body:
Caveat; I don't know if this is actually required by the SMTP protocol, but it appears that using sendmailer with https://github.com/bruceg/nullmailer causes a bug identfied in their changelog as https://github.com/bruceg/nullmailer/commit/4d89f70c1e2e414444d1e5087685e3deec3d2f0f, "Growing recipient list when sending multiple messages", in which the first message is sent to the intended recipient of the first message, the second message is sent to the intended recipients of the first two messages, and so on.

This appears to occur with swiftmailer <= 5.0.3 and nullmailer <1.13

This is no issue if you have the latest nullmailer, but distros are still packing rather older versions. If it's not a strict requirement to send RSET, would doing so anyway be permitted in SMTP spec, and would it aid compatibility?

issue.title: AbstractSmtpTransport::_isFqdn() let's wildcard hostnames pass -> SMTP error
issue.body:
Hi,

when using nginx with a wildcard server entry like
`server_name *.mydomain.de`
this server-name ist passed to AbstractSmtpTransport::_isFqdn() which accepts this as an fqdn entry and uses it as HELO. Which in return will fail on most MTAs (e.g. exim4).

I will try and prepare a PR in the next few days.

kind regards,
Tobias

issue.title: [PATCH] Excessive memory use by Swift_CharacterReader_Utf8Reader
issue.body:
I've had a few processes die in Utf8Reader.php - didn't catch a stack trace:

```
[12-Aug-2013 21:27:31] PHP Fatal error:  Allowed memory size of 536870912 bytes exhausted (tried to allocate 71 bytes) in /redacted/lib/classes/Swift/CharacterReader/Utf8Reader.php on line 127
[12-Aug-2013 22:28:06] PHP Fatal error:  Allowed memory size of 536870912 bytes exhausted (tried to allocate 32 bytes) in /redacted/lib/classes/Swift/CharacterReader/Utf8Reader.php on line 98
```

The issue seems to be populating `$currentMap`, which is only called from `Swift_CharacterStream_NgCharacterStream` to do some UTF8 validation.

Is there an option to bypass UTF8 validation and skip making these extra copies of the entire message? (The message is nowhere near 512MB, i'll look into getting a better stack trace)

My Symfony2 project contains a contact form which contains a Swiftmailer extension to send contact mails to an account. It's for a site with estate properties. Estate managers can put their offers online while visitors - if they are interested in an offer - can contact the manager through a contact form. 

My problem is that when the smtp is down or in maintenance (always possible) that i am unable to provide a service to tell the user to retry later. This library sends an Swift_TransportException if the smtp host fails to respond within a predefined timespan. I have inserted the swift command in a try-catch block and catching the error. But php fails to catch this custom exception. Even the global exception fails to catch this exception.

More information (and also code snippet) can be found on a question that i have put on StackOverflow, http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17695896/swiftmailer-swift-transportexception-gets-uncaught-by-try-catch-block. 

I hope that someone here can provide a solution. Thank you.

issue.title: Make assertValidAddress accessible to validate email address before exception
Allow Message-ID to be passed with the enclosing brackets
issue.body:
When setting a Message-ID using setId(), the enclosing brackets ("<" and ">") are automatically added by Swift Mailer.
When I include the brackets in the setId()-call myself, I get a "Swift_RfcComplianceException".

Improvement suggestion: Detect if the brackets are already there. If yes, set the Message-ID exactly as given with setId(). If no, add the brackets as before.

Cheers,
Thomas

issue.title: SwiftMailer sends eMail to wrong address
issue.body:
I experienced a seemingly very rare problem were an email got send to a wrong mail address. We are sending thousands of mails a day and this never happened before. Here is the setup: 1. Get about 100 recipients from database 2. Loop through and always using this code snippet: ``` php $mailer = Swift_Mailer::newInstance($transport); $message = Swift_Message::newInstance() ->setSubject($Subject) ->setFrom(array($FromEmail => $FromName)) ->setTo(array($To)); $message->setBody($TextMessage, 'text/plain'); if($mailer->send($message)) return true; return false; ``` As you can see, we use no method of cache cleaning etc. as SwiftMail, to my knowledge, does not expose these methods public in the classes. When we sent these mails following error occured during the loop: ``` php An error (2) occurred on line 279 and in the file: /***/Swift-4.2.1/lib/classes/Swift/KeyCache/DiskKeyCache.php.

fopen(/tmp/51db11d138c05/body): failed to open stream: No such file or directory

array ( 'UNIQUE_ID' => 'UdsR0VUNlNkAAEqIiMcAAAAS', 'GEOIP_CONTINENT_CODE' => 'EU', 'GEOIP_COUNTRY_CODE' => 'NL', 'GEOIP_COUNTRY_NAME' => 'Netherlands', 'HTTP_ACCEPT' => '*/*', 'HTTP_CONNECTION' => 'close', 'PATH' => '/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin', 'SERVER_SIGNATURE' => '', 'SERVER_SOFTWARE' => 'Apache', 'SERVER_PORT' => '80', 'REMOTE_PORT' => '59591', 'REMOTE_USER' => 'admin', 'AUTH_TYPE' => 'Basic', 'GATEWAY_INTERFACE' => 'CGI/1.1', 'SERVER_PROTOCOL' => 'HTTP/1.1', 'REQUEST_METHOD' => 'GET', 'QUERY_STRING' => '', 'REQUEST_URI' => '/postProcess.php', 'SCRIPT_NAME' => '/postProcess.php', 'PHP_SELF' => '/postProcess.php', 'REQUEST_TIME_FLOAT' => 1373311441.12, 'REQUEST_TIME' => 1373311441, 'argv' => array ( ), 'argc' => 0, )array ( ) ``` AS you can see, we are using Swift 4.2.1. In the next iteration of the run, which is retried every 5 minutes, the email got sent to the address of the new user BUT with the old body. To clarify here again: 1. Pick User X from array 2. Build mail and send message 3. Pick User X+1 from array 4. Try to send 5. => Exception 6. Retry on script restart with User X+1 7. Mail gets send to User X+1 BUT with body intended for user X. Subject etc. is however correctly set to be for user X+1 When I walk through the code, Swift Mailer determines a change of the body through ``` php if ($body !== $this->_body) { $this->_clearCache(); } ``` Could it be that if fopen returns NULL by reading from an empty or non-existent handle AT THE TIME, and we use newInstance (wich sets body to NULL by default) Swift thinks the body did not change. But THEN upon sending, the handle gets available again and it reads the old message? Hope this report is thorough enough to work with. The problem seems to be rare, but I think a major issue in its impact.

issue.title: 55x return codes in AbstractSmtpTransport
issue.body:
It seems to me that 55x codes (eg. mailbox full) should possibly not be throwing an exception, rather just mark the recipient as failed.

Our main use case is for the 554 in AWS SES blacklist, which gets triggered quite a bit.  We've implemented a TransportExceptionListener which then cancel the event if we're in a certain state, etc, but it seems very clunky.  Could create a new SES transport agent to just override the send event, which would be slightly better, however, it still feels a bit wrong.  

If I were to update the AbstractSmtpTransport to allow 55x codes, but mark as failed recipients, would that break a lot of existing functionality?  Perhaps a flag in the class to toggle that behaviour?

issue.title: Some issues with the file spool when messages fail
issue.body:
Recently I encountered some difficulties with the file spool feature (in conjunction with SwiftmailerBundle's `SendEmailCommand` command). This was also my topic on the KnpUniversity Q&A day and my question was analysed in depth at https://knpuniversity.com/screencast/question-answer-day/swiftmailer-spooling. The solution was a workaround and I'm currently helping myself with a similar approach.

But nonetheless I think the `Swift_FileSpool` may need some improvements:
1. What is the reason for `Swift_FileSpool`'s attributes `$_path` and `$_retryLimit` being declared as `private`? To implement my workaround in a customized child class I was struggling with overriding some methods (`recover()` and `flushQueue()`) because I have no  access to these properties. So I had to copy all the coode down to my child class. I could not use an independent class because SwiftmailerBundle's `SendEmailCommand` command requires an `Swift_FileSpool` instance.
2. `Swift_FileSpool::flushQueue()`: I'm using Amazons SES service via SMTP. When sending out thousands of mails every day it is likely to sometimes receive a permanent  SMTP error for some reasons (e.g. _recepient blacklisted_ or _sender not verified_). This causes `$transport->send()` to throw an `Swift_TransportException` which is not catched and kills the remaining sendouts. There are four problems with this:
   - You won't get informed about the sent mails before the error (`$count` variable)
   - You won't get informed about what mail has failed
   - No more mails are sent after the error, but it seems that we could recover from an error for a particular mail - all the mails afterwards could be ok and would not need to wait for  the next queue flush.
   - Supposed to flush the queue every minute via cron and supposed to use the default interval for recovery (15 minutes): As soon as more than 15 messages with permanent errors have accumulated in the spool directory - no email at all will be sent any more. This is because the first failed message recovers afters 15 minutes and fails again with the sending process completely aborted. One minute later it's the same with the second message and so on.  

In my workaround I've created a customized child class of `Swift_FileSpool`. I'm catching  `Swift_TransportException`s for the `$transport->send()` call in `flushQueue()` to continue with the "good"  messages in the same process - currently not beeing able to log that. To get rid of permanently failing messages I've added a second parameter `$recoverLimit=3` to the `recover()` method. It is used to indicate how many attempts for recovery should be made. All spooled message files are removed after `$recoverLimit*$timeout` seconds.

I'm not really happy with my temporary solution and I also don't want to create a second cron job for cleaning up things. I think the `Swift_FileSpool` could be improved to handle message failures but I'm not to deep in the code to find the right approach. But I would really like to help improving the process if someone can point me in the right direction. For issue 1) I could create a PR.

Thank you,
Philipp

issue.title: Compilation failed: internal error: previously-checked referenced subpattern not found
Cannot forward message as attachment
issue.body:
In one of our projects, a webmail, there's the standard functionality for the user to be able to forward a given message as attachment.

I find impossible to do this only by using SwiftMailer.

While using Swift_Attachment is okay for regular uses, it cannot handle the message/rfc822 spec. An example of why it can't do it is that it has to have two Content-Type headers:
- one for the mime part of the email
  
  ```
  Content-Type: message/rfc822;
    name="=?UTF-8?B?0JzQsNC70LrQviDQutC40YDQuNC70LjRhtCwLmVtbA==?="
  ```
- one for the forwarded message
  
  ```
  Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
  ```

Also the headers of the forwarded message has to be separated from the mime-part headers with one empty line.

I've tried using Swift_Message, since the Swift_Message::attach() method requires an implementation of the Swift_Mime_MimeEntity interface and it's one. Unfortunately, this did not worked as well.

It seem to me like we need another class which would combine the Swift_Message and Swift_Attachment, so we can specify the attachment filename. It can default to the message subject, but we have to be able to change it. An example class name might be Swift_Message_Rfc822.

issue.title: problems with mail() transport and safe_mode

Memory leak in StreamBuffer ( stream_socket_client / stream_context_create )
issue.body:
I have a long-running CLI PHP script that sends out emails and I believe there is a memory leak in StreamBuffer:
https://github.com/swiftmailer/swiftmailer/blob/master/lib/classes/Swift/Transport/StreamBuffer.php#L253

I think it may be caused by this underlying PHP bug:
https://bugs.php.net/bug.php?id=61371&edit=1

I am not sure if there is a workaround for this, but I wanted to mention the issue in case somebody else runs has the same problem.  If I comment out this line:
`$this->_stream = @stream_socket_client($host.':'.$this->_params['port'], $errno, $errstr, $timeout, STREAM_CLIENT_CONNECT, stream_context_create($options));`
And replace it with this, to simulate an inability to connect:
`$this->_stream = false;`
Then there is no leak.

I tried unsetting $errno and $errstr variables as well as the $_stream class variable, but none of these fixed the leak.

I am using PHP 5.3.10.

issue.title: Fix email subject with special characters (e.g. UTF-8) in Outlook
issue.body:
Following up & fixing #70, #79 and #185. Outlook 2003 and later does not correctly handle "folding" in the subject, resulting in a totally broken emails (see http://cloud.iserv.ch/G9GF).

I removed the code folding entirely. Interesting is that "folding" is actually only applied to strings that need encoding, that is why the issue never appeared with ASCII-only subjects and only happens if your subject happens to match a certain string length where the encoded part is folded.

This might also be threaded as a SwiftMailer bug, but because it was not taken care of as of now, I think the best solution (to support Outlook) is not to apply it on encoding either.

issue.title: Alternative file spool implementation.
issue.body:
Provides a new Swift_SerializedFileSpool class as an alternative to the standard Swift_FileSpool class.

Main benefits is that it can use the igbinary_serialize and gzcompress functions if available to further reduce the size of spool files. It also provides a bit more control over the generated spool files.

Most of the changes could have been incorporated into the existing spool class but there are are a few slight differences in implementation. Having a new class with slightly different naming conventions can also ensure that even if the two spool classes use he same directory they won't walk over each other.

$img_data = create_my_image_data();

What's missing is what exactly is allowed to be the return value of the `create_my_image_data` function. I tried using the output of  GD lib's `imagecreatetruecolor` as suggested but that doesn't seem to work, the email does not contain valid images (and seemingly no images at all):

I am mistaken to assume I can pass the GD image handle into this function?

issue.title: Exception messages from _doRcptToCommand should not be discarded
issue.body:
AbstractSmtpTransport::_doMailTransaction catches instances of Swift_TransportException yielded by calls to _doRcptToCommand and handles them by only listing a failed recipient while simultaneously discarding the exception message.

This hides information the mail server is trying to convey about the reasons for rejecting a recipient. This makes debugging harder and hinders informative error reporting.

A possible solution would be to either change the filling of $failedRecipients (which could break legacy client code) or extend the interface definition by (a) an additional feedback array or (b) an optional flag to select an "extended" format for $failedRecipients.

issue.title: Decorator Plugin Using Same Data for everyone
issue.body:
I'm not sure if it is a bug or it's the way I've put together my email processor, but for some reason emails using the same replacement fields (but different contents) are using the exact same data as the first email sent out, but only if it is in the same output cycle (basically my script checks for new email to send every 5 minutes and loops around until there is something to send).

What's more strange is that I'm sending email one at a time (so it's not like I'm batching it).

I've outputted the replacement data (to cron email) to pass to the decorator plugin and the replacements are 100% correct. I've gone deep into the plugin and outputted the message data to cron email and that suggests that once a replacement is made, it is stuck there if the same email template is passed through.

Could it be that my emailer is a class, and within it (in a function) i'm creating a new instance of the decorator plugin (though i don't see any other way to pass the replacements to the plugin) before doing all the processing and email building as normal?

If this is a bug, I hope this helps - if not, then maybe I'm doing something wrong in my emailing class (but I don't think I am) otherwise I guess I have to use str_replace (or something) to replace every replaceable....

issue.title: Handling iso-2022-jp encoding for base64
issue.body:
Header encoding for base64 does not work in JIS code (iso-2022-jp).
base64_encode is working properly, but splitting 76 characters cannot handle after encoding. To do this, we have to check each character to encode to base64.
The easiest way to solve this is using mb_encode_mimeheader, but the usage of mb_encode_mimeheader is not very clean, since we always have to set mb_internal_encoding before calling mb_encode_mimeheader. And after using it, re-set the mb_internal_encoding again.

Also, I would like to mention using iconv functions or mbstring functions. iconv functions cannot handle some Japanese texts, so we have to check the existence of mbstring earlier than iconv functions.

Actually, I'm working with this right now, and will pull request when it finished.

issue.title: Decorator Plugin 'stuck' on first entry.
Nagle delays affect mail sending throughput
issue.body:
Since upgrading from V3 to V4 we had noticed that the sending throughput dropped to 10 mails per second (with the bottleneck not being mail generation or MTA, but some kind of "waiting delay that generates no server load). 

It has taken quite some time to get to the bottom of this but we finally got there. This is all done against Swift Mailer 4.04, but I have checked the code in 4.1 and it is the same. It turns out that the reason is Nagle Delays:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nagle%27s_algorithm

We are using postfix as our MTA, so I posted this to the postfix users list:

http://archives.neohapsis.com/archives/postfix/2011-07/0009.html

Here is the answer from the man who wrote postfix:

http://archives.neohapsis.com/archives/postfix/2011-07/0011.html

So the problem is that Swift mailer:

a) sends the "<CR><LF>.<CR><LF>" separately from the message body

b) uses an fsockopen stream which does not have the full set of socket options (if using the socket_extension it would be possible to set TCP_NODELAY to eliminate Nagle delays http://www.php.net/manual/en/function.socket-get-option.php ).

This effectively limits the throughput to just 10 mails per second in our setup which had system wide nagle wait time set to 100ms (the default for FreeBSD). 

As a workaround I changed the system wide Nagle delay as described in my response on the postfix list:

http://archives.neohapsis.com/archives/postfix/2011-07/0018.html

> So I changed the system wide Nagle behaviour on the server, which is a freebsd system. 
> 
> http://lists.freebsd.org/pipermail/freebsd-stable/2008-June/043325.html
> 
> sysctl net.inet.tcp.delacktime=10 
> (default 100ms)
> 
> Which reduced 90% of the delay.
> 
> Not ideal, but fine in this case, since most of the traffic to that host is LAN or very high speed WAN.

Oliver

issue.body:

@@@
Ghlldnkdrper Melinda/Zqvexmilkré

if (!preg_match('/^' . $this->_grammar['phrase'] . '$/D', $phraseStr))

issue.title: php.ini sendmail_path with envelope sender param fails Swift_MailTransport to send messages
issue.body:
PHP is running with safe_mode = off, so Swift_Transport_SimpleMailInvoker::mail() passes ExtraParams to mail() function, but it fails to send messages if sendmail_path in php.ini is set with envelope sender param:
@@@
/usr/sbin/sendmail -t -i -fwebmaster@example.com
@@@

I'm using Swift-4.0.6

This is uncommon case, I haven't experienced till today. The only workaround I found, is removing extraParams from passing to mail() function in Swift_Transport_SimpleMailInvoker::mail(), but it must be left there for cases when sendmail_path is set without envelope sender param. So there is need for automated sendmail_path checking or at least some fail check, for example
@@@
if(!($result = mail($to, $subject, $body, $headers, $extraParams))){
  $result = mail($to, $subject, $body, $headers);
}
return result;
@@@

issue.title: Email body repeating since release 4.0.6
issue.body:
Let me start by saying I love SwiftMailer.  Awesome product.  Have used this now for years.  We have sent millions of messages using SwiftMailer.

Problem:  We send out over 20,000 HTML messages per day using SwiftMailer using two different servers.  One server (Mail1) has been upgraded to 4.0.6 the other (Mail0) is on the prior release.  In some cases, instances of a message are received with part of the message body repeating after the "end" of the original message body.

In all cases with repeating content the final HTML tag is not closed and the repeating content begins after that.  The additional content is a repeat of the original content split  just after an MS Word character like a Smart quote or a curly apostrophe.  Imagine using the result from list($junk,$repeatingcontent)=explode('microsoft smart quote',$messagebody,2) .  The $repeatingcontent is then added to the end of the document.  The final HTML tag is not closed and the same explode is done on $repeatingcontent until nothing is left and the message finally ends.

MS Word characters in the message body appear to be the cause however, this has been a tough bug to track down as it is not happening in all messages.  I receive many of the messages myself and have only one instance of such a message arriving in my inbox whilst other recipients of the same message have the problem occuring in their copy

Originally I suspected email client problems and badly formed HTML tables in the message.  I have eliminated all of these possibilities over a period of several weeks.

I started logging every message body after we had loaded it into SwiftMailer with the personalisation all in place to ensure it was nothing I was doing in my loop.  There was not one instance at my end.

After logging enough of these events I could compare the original HTML, my log of what was loaded into swift and check which server was used.  This is when I noticed that the old version on Mail0 was not causing the issue.

With more substantial series of tests I confirmed this and finally received a copy of a message with the issue from an email message I had instigated.  The issue was repeatable and identical and only accured when using SwiftMailer 4.0.6.

Once I had a copy that I could repeat the bug (sending one proof message at a time) that came to my inbox I could look at the received code and find the MS Word character link.

I will make these characters safe as a probable workaround however it might be something to look at at your end also.

I would have attached the files however they are too large for this service.  I can provide if required.

Thanks in advance.

Mark

Original reporter: Mark

SwiftMailer should somehow fix the mail addresses for Windows platforms.

issue.title: SMTP Transport breaks HELO on Mac OS X due to IPv6
issue.body:
This is an easy one to fix. :)

When creating an Swift_SmtpTransport it, by default, tries to use the local server name ($_SERVER['SERVER_NAME']). If this server name is "localhost" (which it often is on a developer machine) then it fails the _isFqdn() check (which it rightly should) and the transport then defaults to using $_SERVER['SERVER_ADDR']. It does not, however, check whether this address against _isFqdn which it should. 

On Mac OS X 10.5, SERVER_ADDR will often be ::1 which is an IPv6 address not compatible with (some/all?) SMTP servers resulting in a "501 5.5.4 Invalid Address" response to "HELO [::1]".

The fix would be to additionally check whether SERVER_ADDR is a full qualified domain name (or valid IP) and if not then just default to 127.0.0.1 which would be better than nothing.

Original creation date: 2009-07-22T15:34:22Z
Original reporter: Patrick Hogan

issue.title: Non-Ascii characters stripped from attachment names (1st char only)
issue.body:
I use UTF-8 encoding for sending mails. If I add a file with the name "Řeřicha.txt" the Ř character is stripped.

Swift produces:

--_=_swift_v4_12456688804a3f66105fa38_=_
Content-Type: text/plain; name="=?utf-8?Q?e=C5=99icha=2Etxt?="
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64

How can I fix this?

character encoding troubles
issue.body:
Hello.
There is some character encoding bug I guess. I think I need output in ISO-8859-2 because the email clients here like it. UTF-8 in headers doesn't not work correct in Outlook for example.

Most of the characters are OK, but some of them are encoded differently. For example, the little "s" with cedilla is encoded as a "=9A" and the Outlook needs it to be "=B9". I don't know why it has to be B9 when 9A is right.

I would like to make some str_replace at output to solve this problem. And I would like to know, where to do it( a place where the string is encoded already). I hope it helps to others too.

issue.title: setBody() + addPart() with embedded images doesn't correctly add multipart/alternative entity
issue.body:
The following code: @@@ php setSubject('See my image'); $msg -> setFrom(array('swift@example.com')); $msg -> setTo(array('thunderbird@example.com'=>'Thunderbird Client')); $msg -> setBody("This is the plain text you'll see when I try and embed an image."); //Image to embed $cid = $msg->embed(Swift_Image::fromPath('logo.png')); $img = '

'; // HTML body $msg -> addPart( "

See my logo

" . "

Outlook works, Thunderbird will fall back to plain text and show the " . "HTML body (as Part 1.2) and the image as attachments

" . $img, ``` 'text/html' ``` ); //Transport and Mailer $transport = Swift_MailTransport::newInstance(); $mailer = Swift_Mailer::newInstance($transport); if($mailer->send($msg)) { echo "Message Sent"; } @@@ Creates a structure similar to the following: @@@ Content-Type: multipart/related; boundary="relbound" --relbound Content-Type: text/plain Plain text here --relbound Content-Type: text/html HTML here --relbound Content-Type: image/png --relbound-- @@@ There should be a multipart/alternative entity wrapping this: @@@ Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="altbound" --altbound Content-Type: text/plain Plain text here --altbound Content-Type: multipart/related; boundary="relbound" --relbound Content-Type: text/html HTML here --relbound Content-Type: image/png --relbound-- --altbound-- @@@ Probably a simple fix (I seem to remember fixing a similar bug which should have test coverage now). Hopefully there's no conflict of logic between the two. Original creation date: 2009-03-23T09:06:36Z Original reporter: Ben Original ticket: http://swiftmailer.lighthouseapp.com/projects/21527/tickets/77

issue.title: Investigate using maps to optimize ArrayCharacterStream
Add support for 8BITMIME
issue.body:
Using an ESMTP extension handler, as provided by the Swift Mailer API, create an extension that manages 8BITMIME.

This may be difficult to do in a way that does not permanently modify a user's message, yet still takes advantage of caching (caching may need to be cleverly managed by the extension handler).

8BITMIME allows clients to send messages over SMTP using full 8-bit characters as opposed to the traditional restriction of allowing only 7-bit characters as specified in RFC 2822.  With the exception of the headers, which must ALWAYS be 7-bit only.

The extension will need to store instances of an 8bit transfer encoder and QP transfer encoder, which it can swap-out at runtime, immediately before sending.

If the ESMTP handler API does not suffice, enhance it.

Try to make sure caching is used and is not repeatedly busted by overwriting the encoder, but at the same time, ensure that the message is not permanently modified to use 8-bit encoding (the message that is provided to `send()` should have the same encoding as the message after it is sent).  This brings up some interesting challenges with how to manage the cache here.

8BITMIME will significantly improve performance by avoiding the use of QP encoding where available.

Full RFC:

http://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1652.txt

Original creation date: 2009-03-09T14:37:11Z
Original reporter: Chris Corbyn
Original ticket: http://swiftmailer.lighthouseapp.com/projects/21527/tickets/68

issue.title: Rewrite CharacterStream and dependencies based on Java
issue.body:
This is a massive bottleneck when comparing v3 to v4.  v3 did not do anything at all to manage character encodings, and thus it has major bugs in its QP encoding logic.  v4 has fixed this, but at the expense of speed.

No real research was done in the area of the algorithms used to read character streams and as such, it's more than likely an existing (object-oriented) implementation can be adapted and work a lot faster than the current implementation.

Read through the source of Java's InputStreamReader and dependencies (namely StreamDecoder):

http://www.docjar.com/html/api/java/io/InputStreamReader.java.html
http://www.docjar.com/html/api/sun/nio/cs/StreamDecoder.java.html

Follow their dependencies and try to base our implementation off of this... Java tackled this long before we ever did and their OO approach should translate quite nicely.

End-user docs for those Java classes:

http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/guide/io/io.html

Don't be fooled.  This is a massive undertaking that will mostly likely ripple throughout the encoder components of Swift Mailer.

Original creation date: 2009-03-09T14:25:15Z
Original reporter: Chris Corbyn
Original ticket: http://swiftmailer.lighthouseapp.com/projects/21527/tickets/66

issue.title: Add setEncoder() to HeaderSet and Header
issue.body:
Another weak point that has shown up whilst writing the documentation.  It's possible to change the encoding of the message itself, but it's not possible to change the Header encoding from Q to B.

Add getQEncoding() and getBEncoding() methods to Swift_Encoding, and add setEncoder() methods to Swift_Mime_Header and Swift_Mime_HeaderSet (possibly also Swift_Mime_HeaderFactory).

issue.title: Change IoBuffer interface to disambiguate setParams() method
Change setChildren() to addChild() and removeChild()
issue.body:
The setChildren() method makes things incredibly easy, but it doesn't need to be the public-facing method for dealing with composition.

Decompose this into addChild() and removeChild() methods which delegate to setChildren() internally.

Make setChildren() private _setChildren().

This is going to break a lot of unit tests - be warned!

Original creation date: 2008-12-26T01:18:35Z
Original reporter: Chris Corbyn
Original ticket: http://swiftmailer.lighthouseapp.com/projects/21527/tickets/31

issue.title: Investigate the use of parallel sending with LoadBalancedTransport
issue.body:
The LoadBalancedTransport can cycles through a collection of SMTP servers to distribute sending in order to reduce the load on any single server.

However, a "would-be-nice" is a flag that allowed this transport (or a subclass of it?) to actually process messages to multiple transports in parallel.  Currently it waits for each server to finish sending before it moves to the next.

Obviously PHP can't multi-thread, but because SMTP connections are TCP/Socket based there may be some trickery involving non-blocking connections that can be used.

We may need to write a PIPELINING extension to do this in one-hit per server.

Original creation date: 2008-12-24T11:16:34Z

Create a MultibyteCharacterReader implementation that uses the MB String library when available.  Register this class in the DI container or Swift_Preferences in the presence of the MB String library.

name: rs_classcolors
description: Text colorizing mod for World of Warcraft
readme:
h1. Overview

RS_ClassColors colorizes player names by their class colors (as shown in the raid window). Player names that appear in the chat log, the friends list, the /who results list, the guild roster, and the battlegrounds scoreboard will be colored by class. You have the additional option of leaving offline players colored gray.

A player's class is garnered from the guild roster, friends list, party/raid list, or results of a recent /who query. If the player is not in any of these lists (e.g., he is some random n00b spamming in Orgrimmar/Ironforge), his name will be colored gray until his class can be determined.

Player's classes can be saved from session to session, such that a growing database of players' names and classes is kept. This can of course take up a lot of disk space, so the option is available to turn this off. (It is off by default.)

Along with player names, players' levels and zones can be colorized in the friends list, guild roster, and /who results list. Levels are colored the same as in the target frame, and zones are shaded green if they are the same as your zone.

If you dislike the coloring effect on any particular part of the game, you can turn it off. You can individually control whether or not to color player names in the chat window, battlegrounds scoreboard, guild tab, friends list, or /who results list.

For instructions on how to do all this, please type /rscc after installing the mod.

h2. Version History

*1.4 (Nov 23, 2008)*

* First import into GitHub.
* Now supports WoW 3.0 (WotLK).
* Added Death Knight class.
* Configuration is now done in the WoW Interface Options dialog.

name: ernestine
description: Ernestine is a music management application in McClim.
readme:
Ernestine
=========

[![Build Status](http://img.shields.io/travis/nlamirault/ernestine.svg)](https://travis-ci.org/nlamirault/ernestine)


Ernestine is a music management application.
see INSTALL file for more explanations.

2 frontends exists :
* a McClim player.
* a web radio in Flash.

## McCLim Player

### Dependencies

Install theses packages :

    $ sudo apt-get install mp3info aumix mplayer

### Launch the mcclim frontend

    CL-USER> (asdf:oos 'asdf:load-op :ernestine-gui)
    CL-USER> (ernestine-gui:player)

Add you music with the **C-i** command or Music button.
Put  in the line  the directory  which contains  you music  files. You
could use the File Browser (Browse button).
Then start the music scanning with the "Search" button.

### Available commands from the GUI

    C-q : quit ernestine

    C-Return : start playing selected song
    C-Space : stop playing current song

    C-n : next song
    C-p : previous song

    C-a : add to playlist selected song
    C-d : delete selected song from playlist
    C-z : shuffle

    C-i : import music files

    C-s : save current playlist
    C-o : open a file selector to search a playlist

### Screenshots

* [0.4](data/ernestine-mcclim-0.4.png)
* [0.3](data/ernestine-mcclim-0.3.png)
* [0.2](data/ernestine-clx-0.2.png)
* [0.1](data/ernestine-player-0.1.png)


## Web radio

### Launch the web frontend

    CL-USER> (asdf:oos 'asdf:load-op :ernestine-web)

### Creates the web radio

You must specify the virtual  host, the Ernestine source directory and
the port for the web server :

    CL-USER> (defparameter *radio*
                  (ernestine-web:create-web-radio "my.host.info" 9090
                                                  :covers-p t))

If *covers-p* is t, Ernestine will search covers, download and update
database of each album.

### Add music

If all  your music  is store in  directory /opt/music/, you  could add
this directory, and Ernestine will scan recursively all directories to
creates the music database :

    CL-USER> (ernestine-web:add-music *radio* "/opt/music/" t)

The *add-music* method take an optional argument : covers-p. If
it is t, Ernestine will download covers albums.

### Manage the web radio

    CL-USER> (ernestine-web:start-radio *radio*)
    CL-USER> (ernestine-web:stop-radio *radio*)

### Screenshots

* [0.4](data/ernestine-web-0.4.png)
* [0.3](data/ernestine-web-0.3.png)
* [0.3](data/ernestine-web-0.2.png)

## Benchs

Benchmarks of the database backend :

    CL-USER> (time
               (let ((backend (ernestine-database:get-backend :prevalence "/tmp/")))
                 (ernestine-tools:scan-directory backend "/opt/music/")))

### Version 0.2

    Date ; 2007-08-11
    Size : 16G for /opt/music/
    Without covers :
    Evaluation took:
      314.1 seconds of real time
      12.96081 seconds of user run time
      44.514786 seconds of system run time
      [Run times include 0.564 seconds GC run time.]
      0 calls to %EVAL
      0 page faults and
      230,012,408 bytes consed.

    With covers :
    Evaluation took:
      1211.078 seconds of real time
      370.02313 seconds of user run time
      147.08118 seconds of system run time
      [Run times include 188.276 seconds GC run time.]
      32040 calls to %EVAL
      15 page faults and
      93,196,758,304 bytes consed.

### Version 0.1

    Date : 2007-05-08
    Size : 14G for /opt/music
    Evaluation took:
      226.969 seconds of real time
      10.200638 seconds of user run time
      41.40659 seconds of system run time
      [Run times include 0.949 seconds GC run time.]
      0 calls to %EVAL
      0 page faults and
      263,101,968 bytes consed.


## Changelog

A changelog is available [here](ChangeLog.md).


## Contact

Nicolas Lamirault <nicolas.lamirault@gmail.com>

name: restful-authentication
description: Fork of restful-authentication to add ldap support
readme:
Restful Authentication Generator
====

This is a basic restful authentication generator for rails, taken 
from acts as authenticated.  Currently it requires Rails 1.2.6 or above.

To use:

  ./script/generate authenticated user sessions \
		--include-activation \
		--stateful

The first parameter specifies the model that gets created in signup
(typically a user or account model).  A model with migration is 
created, as well as a basic controller with the create method.

The second parameter specifies the sessions controller name.  This is
the controller that handles the actual login/logout function on the 
site.

The third parameter (--include-activation) generates the code for a 
ActionMailer and its respective Activation Code through email.

The fourth (--stateful) builds in support for acts_as_state_machine
and generates activation code.  This was taken from:

http://www.vaporbase.com/postings/stateful_authentication

You can pass --skip-migration to skip the user migration.

If you're using acts_as_state_machine, define your users resource like this:

	map.resources :users, :member => { :suspend   => :put,
                                     :unsuspend => :put,
                                     :purge     => :delete }

Also, add an observer to config/environment.rb if you chose the 
--include-activation option

  config.active_record.observers = :user_observer # or whatever you 
																									# named your model

Security Alert
====

I introduced a change to the model controller that's been tripping 
folks up on Rails 2.0.  The change was added as a suggestion to help
combat session fixation attacks.  However, this resets the Form 
Authentication token used by Request Forgery Protection.  I've left
it out now, since Rails 1.2.6 and Rails 2.0 will both stop session
fixation attacks anyway.

name: rspec_spinner
readme:
= rspec_spinner

For RSpec 2 there's a new gem working:

https://github.com/jeffkreeftmeijer/fuubar


= Not maintained

Adds extra formatters that looks like this:

  Foo::Error ......
  SLOW SPEC: 10.0314  Foo should raise Bar
  PENDING SPEC: Foo should get Bar
  891/1808:  49% |=======================                        | ETA:  00:00:21


Or this:

  46%  \   should get Bar                                          ETA:  00:00:23


No dots and Fs, just what you need to know: FAILURES, PENDINGS and SLOW ones.


== Install

  gem install rspec_spinner


== Use

Require RspecSpinner on spec/spec_helper.rb:

  require 'spec'
  require 'rspec_spinner'
  ...


=== Rspec 2.x

Add to your project /.rspec

  --require rspec_spinner --format RspecSpinner::Bar

or:

  --require rspec_spinner --format RspecSpinner::Spinner


=== Rspec 1.x

Change your spec.opts --format to:

  --format RspecSpinner::Bar

or:

  --format RspecSpinner::Spinner


Have fun!


== Requirements

* rtui  (http://github.com/nofxx/rtui)

Works with:

* rspec (http://github.com/dchemlinksy/rspec)
* ...Need to work in an agnostic version...


== License

(The MIT License)

Based on the Advanced Progress Bar by Nicholas A. Evans

Copyright (c) 2008 Marcos Piccinini

name: .profile.d
readme:
# .profile.d

## Why

Rather than store all of my configuration settings in a huge file. 

I decided to store each "group" of settings in their own file.

## Install

 * Backup your existing ```~/.bash_profile``` - it's about to be replaced
 * ```git clone``` this repo into ~/.profile.d 
 * ```$ cd ~/.profile.d```
 * ```$ ./setup.sh```

## Hacking

 * You can add new extensions in the ```extensions/``` subdirectory
 * Use ```$ up``` to reload without having to log back in
 * ```.profile.d/work*``` are .gitignored, so you can name an extension, for example, ```extensions/work-secretstuff``` you might not want to share.
  * This will also keep an as-yet-unwritten unrelated extension from clobbering your local ones.

My homepage is HTML5 + RDFa. At the bottom of the page there are icons, each
of which has a link. The HTML5 and CSS icons lead to validation reports. The
last icon extracts the RDF statements that are embedded in this page.

The slidebar and other interactivity (menus, (un)folding) is created by Lars
Willighagen (see the commits).

name: ffmpegger
description: Why should high quality video encoding be hard?
readme:
= ffmpegger

Easy as pie:

  Ffmpegger.convert "#{File.dirname(__FILE__)}/samples/cb.mov" do
    resolution "720x480"
    bitrate "500"
  end

Look at ffmpegger.rb to see the options that are editable currently for ffmpeg. Based on the super sweet high quality conversion from http://www.flashcomguru.com/index.cfm/2008/2/2/jaw-drop-h264

== LICENSE:

name: incrementnumberfield
description: [Symphony 2] A Number Field whose value increases by 1 each time the entry is pulled through a Data Source
readme:
# Increment Number Field

Increments a number each time an entry is shown in a page. Useful for simple hit counters and generating sorted "most popular" lists for your content.

## Installation

1. Upload the `incrementnumberfield` folder in this archive to your Symphony `extensions` folder.
2. Enable it by selecting "Increment Number" on the Extensions page.
3. You can now add the "Increment Number" field to your sections.

## Usage

Add the field to a section. When selecting these entries via a data source choose between the two output modes:

* `view` returns the current value
* `increment` will increase the value by `1` when the data source executes

name: scriptaculous
description: script.aculo.us is an open-source JavaScript framework for visual effects and interface behaviours.
readme:
== script.aculo.us web 2.0 javascript

The Web is changing. The 30-year-old terminal-like technology it was originally 
is gradually giving way to new ways of doing things. The power of AJAX allows 
for rich user interaction without the trouble that has bugged traditional 
web applications. 

Building upon the wonderful Prototype JavaScript library, script.aculo.us 
provides you with some great additional ingredients to mix in.

For more information, see http://script.aculo.us/

== What's new in this release?

See the CHANGELOG file for information on what's new.

You can follow http://twitter.com/scriptaculous if you want
to be updated as we fix bugs and add new features.

== Installation/Usage

script.aculo.us includes the Prototype JavaScript Framework 
V1.6.0. You can use later versions, as they become available 
(see http://prototypejs.org/).

Put prototype.js, and the six files scriptaculous.js, 
builder.js, effects.js, dragdrop.js, controls.js and slider.js 
in a directory of your website, e.g. /javascripts.

(The sound.js and unittest.js files are optional)

Now, you can include the scripts by adding the following 
tags to the HEAD section of your HTML pages:

 <script src="/javascripts/prototype.js" type="text/javascript"></script>
 <script src="/javascripts/scriptaculous.js" type="text/javascript"></script>

scriptaculous.js will automatically load the other files of the 
script.aculo.us distribution in, provided they are accessible 
via the same path.

See http://wiki.script.aculo.us/scriptaculous/show/Usage for detailed
usage instructions.

== The distribution

Besides the script.aculo.us files in src, there's a complete
test tree included which holds functional and unit tests for
script.aculo.us.

If you need examples on how to implement things, the best place to
start is by opening test/run_functional_tests.html or 
test/run_unit_tests.html in your browser, and looking at
the sources of the examples provided.

== License

script.aculo.us is licensed under the terms of the MIT License, 
see the included MIT-LICENSE file.

issue.title: Got file download & empty items
issue.body:
When I went to the json feed URL, Firefox asked me to download the JSON file. I opened it and it just had the first part of the json, without items and without a callback function.

This worked for me though:
http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/json-feed/

name: dbmail
readme:
> 
>   (c) 2004-2014 NFG Net Facilities Group BV, The Netherlands, support@nfg.nl
>
>   (c) 2000-2005 IC&S, The Netherlands
>

What is it?
===========

DBMail is a collection of programs that enables email to be stored in and
retrieved from a database. 

Read the INSTALL file for installation of DBMail.

Why is it useful?
==================

- it enables you to create mailboxes without the need of systemusers.

- mail is more effeciently stored and therefore it can be inserted an
retrieved much faster dan any regular system (DBMail is currently able to
retrieve aprox. 250 mail messages per second)

- It's scalable. You can run the dbmail programs on different servers
talking to the same database(cluster).

- It is more secure. There's no need to maintain system users or write to
the filesystem. All this is done through the database.


Who created it?
===============

Eelco van Beek <eelco@ic-s.nl> at first created a very sloppy version of
this program which didn't work at all.

Because the DBMail mailing system is big he needed help. 
So he asked Roel <roel@ic-s.nl>, one of the people working with him 
at IC&S, to join in developing DBMail further.

In 2003 Ilja Booij joined IC&S to work on the 2.x version. During that time,
Paul Stevens at NFG also joined the development team, initially to provide 
debian packaging, later to take over development of the 2.1 release. Aaron
Stone also deserves special thanks for initiating the LDAP driver, maintaining 
the delivery chain and of course sieve support.

DBMail is now a community effort to create a fast, effecient and scalable
database driven mailingsystem. Both IC&S and NFG are fully behind 
opensource and the GPL. Therefore DBMail has the GPL licence.

Both IC&S and NFG provide commercial support and consultancy for this
product. For more information about this you can send an email to
info@ic-s.nl and/or support@nfg.nl.

>
> Disclaimer: IC&S nor NFG are responsible for any damages resulting from use 
> of this software. 
>

It should work with almost no problem. We have clients that run dbmail
with more than 25.000 useraccounts. The system is stable.

How do i install it?
====================

Check the different README files and the wiki pages on dbmail.org for detailed 
information and howtos.

Future
======

Check the website for further DBMail plans.

What kind of licence is DBMail?
===============================

DBMail uses the GPL version 2 licence. 

It's included in the COPYING file.
-------------------------------------------

Disconnect IMAP clients if only few free FDs left (#37)

After network connection to DB server goes down the processing of IMAP session
stalls: DB connection pool becomes exhausted as active connections do not
close till TCP timeout kicks in (true at least for Oracle). While DBMail still
accepts incoming connections it quickly reaches the RLIMIT_NOFILE and becomes
unresponsive. Send BYE response if the number of opened FDs reaches the
RLIMIT_NOFILE value.

Reschedule listening socket callback after socket errors

Any explicit _sock_cb() return, e.g. after a failed accept() or getpeername()
call leads to an unresponsive dbmail process as _sock_cb() is never
re-scheduled back.

getpeername() is easy to fail with nmap TCP scan:
> sudo nmap -sT -p143,993 192.168.197.140

Which immediately stalls the dbmail:
> Oct 24 07:37:45 etsys dbmail/imap4d[23523]: Info:[server] _sock_cb(+580):
> getpeername::error [Transport endpoint is not connected]
> Oct 24 07:37:45 etsys dbmail/imap4d[23523]: Info:[server] _sock_cb(+580):
> getpeername::error [Transport endpoint is not connected]

Copy header values into a NULL-terminated buffer

Blob buffer returned by db_result_get_blob() cannot be used as a C-string
at least for Oracle DB:

  1. libzdb reuses its ResultSet internal buffer allocated for blobs, hence
     it possible to read over the blob length and get blob data remnants from
     the previous ResultSet_getBlob() call. e.g.:

     > [(Date To Cc From Subject X-Priority Importance Priority Content-Type)]
     > [Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2013 14:33:12 +0200 (CEST)
     >  To: santa15 Oct 2013 14:33:12 +0200 (CEST)
     >  From: 000123125@bgum.portaone.com0200 (CEST)
     >  Subject: 111222 333444m.portaone.com0200 (CEST)
     >  X-priority: 3 (Normal)444m.portaone.com0200 (CEST)
     >  Importance: Normalmal)444m.portaone.com0200 (CEST)]

  2. blob length is not taken into account, there is no guarantee blob buffer
     is null terminated.

Imap: Folder in Cyrillic doesn't show \Haschildren flag (#987)

This was a string-processing error in dm_db.c/mailbox_match_new().
mailbox_match_new() is called at least from two places with a folder name pattern
 that contains '%' (this is for matching subfolders).
In the old version it was not excluding '%' from replacing it (in specific cases)
 with '_' ('&BBoEOARXBDI-/%' => '&BBoEOARXBDI___').
The '%' sign was replaced with '_' in the 'sensitive' part, and that is
 included in the SQL just when there is a utf7-imap-encoded part in the name.
 That's why the bug was reproducible just for names including parts in utf7-imap encoding.
This way there wasn't any match when counting subfolders of eg. Cyrillic folders.

Also a smaller fix was applied to properly change from verbatim to non-verbatim state.
The '-' sign - closing modified BASE64 data - is still part of that data.

Tests extended.

IMAP: fix hierarchy elements masking out real folders in list response (#978)

The \Noselect flag was appearing unexpectedly in specific cases in list command responses.
This was reproducible for '%' wildcard search.
It was caused by the hierarchy elements found earlier and masking out real folders.
 If subfolders appear first in mailboxes_by_regex()'s response, then the
 partial hierarchy name is found before the real folder.
 All partial hierarchy elements receive \Noselect flag, so showing the
 name from the partial match will include this.
We could change the ordering of returned folders in mailboxes_by_regex(),
 but that would be only a workaround.
The real folders should have a higher priority than the hierarchy elements.
Store the found real folders and hierarchy elements into two separate trees
 before writing them out.
Insert folders from the lower priority tree (the hierarchy elements) to the
 higher priority one, except those that are already there.
 This way they won't mask real folders out.
Iterate the higher priority tree, and output folders to the socket.
It was necessary to insert new functions for the two iterations.
Several parts of the code have been refactored.
A new MailBox state info pointer needs to be reserved and stored into these
 trees.
Freeing can happen at different points.

Tests extended.

COPYUID feature (Feature #3789)

http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4315
-----
[Page 2-3:]
The following response codes are extensions to the response codes
defined in [IMAP] section 7.1.

COPYUID

Followed by the UIDVALIDITY of the destination mailbox, a UID set
containing the UIDs of the message(s) in the source mailbox that
were copied to the destination mailbox and containing the UIDs
assigned to the copied message(s) in the destination mailbox,
indicates that the message(s) have been copied to the destination
mailbox with the stated UID(s).

The source UID set is in the order the message(s) were copied; the
destination UID set corresponds to the source UID set and is in
the same order.
-----

ImapSession struct extended with new_ids list.
_do_copy() saves new_ids into this list.
_ic_copy_enter():
 retrieves old and new uids.
 Converts them to string.
 Creates and fills response code buffer.
 Calls SESSION_OK_WITH_RESP_CODE with the buffer's contents.

Test changes:
 ActiveSupport is included.
 Testcase for copy (regressions, answer format and data validity).

(ported and extended based on commit e374300699d18240986fd25ad701bbb4f74afb73)

Conflicts:
	src/imapcommands.c

Signed-off-by: Paul J Stevens <paul@nfg.nl>

APPENDUID feature

http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4315
-----
[Page 2:]
The following response codes are extensions to the response codes
defined in [IMAP] section 7.1.

APPENDUID

Followed by the UIDVALIDITY of the destination mailbox and the UID
assigned to the appended message in the destination mailbox,
indicates that the message has been appended to the destination
mailbox with that UID.
-----

The SESSION_OK macro has been refactored to SESSION_OK_COMMON.
This is to notice if upstream changes the macro (resolving conflicts is better than duplicating code).
The refactored macro enables response codes.
SESSION_OK calls SESSION_OK_COMMON, so that it will behave the same as previously.
SESSION_OK_WITH_RESP_CODE may be used to send OK response with response code.
_ic_append_enter() has been changed:
 Creates a GString buffer.
 Copies the APPENDUID response code's contents to it with g_string_printf().
 Calls SESSION_OK_WITH_RESP_CODE with the buffer's contents.

Test changes:
 MyIMAP extends Net::IMAP.
 Greeting test is now improved.
 Testcase for append (regressions, answer format and data validity).

(ported and extended based on commit 34206bbc83e0a3b0213b698d35f81df090778b4b)

Do not assume that a UNION SELECT will be ordered.

There is no guarantee that the result set of a UNION SELECT will be
ordered either in the order of the sub-SELECTs or based on the first
column.

An explicit ORDER BY clause would (empirically)	be too CPU-intensive.
Instead, use the first column of the result set	to determine which
row is which when reading the results.

	This patch adds single instance storage for headers,
	in an attempt to save storage space, and to make
	lookups faster (Based on a request/idea from
	Michael Monnerie).

issue.title: dbmail fails to start reliably under systemd
issue.body:
The default service files use "forked" service to spawn the working daemons. See RedHat bugzilla #1267031 for details. Fedora 23/EPEL uses its own slight variation of your service files.

I have added an override until the package changes:
# cat /etc/systemd/system/dbmail-imapd.service.d/override.conf

[Unit]
After=nss-lookup.target

[Service]
Type=simple
ExecStart=
ExecStart=/usr/sbin/dbmail-imapd -D

I recommend you replace the service lines as above for all your service files in dbmail/systemd. As I note in the BZ issue, this is both more reliable and more efficient. Using the builtin daemonizing code, although the only option in sysvinit, is not necessary here and prone to problems. '-D' does the right thing for systemd and is a simpler solution than auditing and changing the initialization code for whatever is run amok. I straced these problems down and I suspect that the environment systemd hands your daemons is triggering them to quietly exit and mess up systemd's idea of state in the process- something sysvinit is too dumb to even know about.

I've also added an "After" to force the daemons to serialize behind nss-lookup because they were coming up in parallel with the network services. network.target is too weak while nss-lookup doesn't release until connectivity is sufficient to allow a DNS/NIS query to work. My symptom was an strace that showed an ENOROUTE on various socket calls. The postgres.service call was also insufficient for me because my DB is on another machine and the postfix+dbmail-\* is in a container (VM).

issue.title: Infinite aliases configuration with postfix.
issue.body:
Need of dynamic alias is very common and might get hard to predefine the aliases in the table.

Example:

```
username+A@domain.tld
username+B@domain.tld
```

A workaround I tried was by using recipient query rewrite.

Dependency: Need to install PCRE support for MySQL 
https://github.com/mysqludf/lib_mysqludf_preg  [Issue #19 for Ubuntu](https://github.com/mysqludf/lib_mysqludf_preg/issues/19)

Then update: /etc/postfix/sql-recipients.cf

```
query = SELECT alias FROM dbmail_aliases WHERE alias=preg_replace('/([+][^@]+)/', '', '%s')
```

Restart postfix - ready to go!

issue.title: Remove unnecessary salt from auth method

Enveloped saved for this was ignoring the Message-Id due to explicit check for (=). This fix eliminates the same.

issue.title: systemd/Makefile
issue.body:
Was having trouble installing on Fedora 19, with systemd, Makefile was having issues with

```
 /usr/lib/systemd/system
 /usr/lib/tmpfiles.d
```

Had a permission denied error, traced it back to the Makefile trying creating those directories, but they already exist.

I fixed this by editing systemd/Makefile.in, and removing the lines #397 and #406

```
@SYSTEMD_TRUE@  $(MKDIR_P) $(DESTDIR)$(SYSTEMD_UNIT_DIR)

@SYSTEMD_TRUE@  $(MKDIR_P) $(DESTDIR)$(SYSTEMD_TMPFILES_DIR)
```

I haven't dug any further, but I guess it's not checking for the directories first? Having removed those lines it "make install"s fine now.

Thanks
